I would like to propose the proof of Fermat Last Theorem for exponent 3 as a project. A couple of comments:

  • first of all we already have a formalized proof (see here, in the FltRegular/FltThree/ folder): that proof stays in ‚Ñ§ and I would like to formalize the proof that uses ‚Ñ§[Œ∂‚ÇÉ].
  • Almost all the number theoretic prerequisites are already in mathlib, so the work is totally doable.
  • The final goal is not only to have a proof, but to have a mathlib-ready proof (indeed FLT3 is a special case that does not follow from the general case proved by Wiles).

For these reasons I think it's a very good project especially for students who like number theory (it is a good occasion to learn some beautiful math is you've never seen this proof).

I am going to do it anyway if nobody is interested, so I've prepared a repository here. As you can see I've already structured the proof I want to follow, there are "only" 37 sorry, but most of them are very easy (some of them will maybe need to be split, we will see).

Let me know if you want to participate!
If you've never played with Lean, sorry means "unproved results".
This is the first blue node in the FLT project by the way!
Do you have a reference for the proof you are following ?

To get the repository (assuming Lean and git are installed), one can do

git clone https://github.com/riccardobrasca/flt3.git
lake exe cache get
lake build

the last step should take no more than a couple of minutes (and it should start compiling something like 2410/2412, not 1/2412).
note that copying/pasting the two files inside any other repository depending on mathlib will not work (because it uses a "future" version of mathlib)

To be precise I am following a slightly modified version of the proof, essentially I am not doing case 1 for the more general equation but only for the original one (since case 1 in ‚Ñ§ is easy even in Lean, and it is already in mathlib, while case 1 for the general equation would be annoying).

In particular I am not proving that the more general equation has no solution, but only that it has no solution in case 2, but this is enough to have case 2 in ‚Ñ§ and so FLT3. I guess nobody really cares about the more general equation.

We can discuss this tomorrow, but mathematically we are here: we have a b c : ùìû K (here K is a 3-rd cyclotomic extension of ‚Ñö) such that a^3+b^3=u*c^3, where u : (ùìû K)À£ and ¬¨ Œª ‚à£ a, ¬¨ Œª ‚à£ b and Œª ‚à£ c, where Œª = Œ∑ - 1 and Œ∑ is a fixed 3-rd root of unity (we know all the properties of Œª, for example it is a prime). We also may (and do) assume that Œª ^ 2 ‚à£ a + b.

we know that:

  • Œª ‚à£ (a + Œ∑ * b)
  • Œª ‚à£ (a + Œ∑ ^ 2 * b)
  • ¬¨ Œª ^ 2 ‚à£ (a + Œ∑ * b)
  • ¬¨ Œª ^ 2 ‚à£ (a + Œ∑ ^ 2 * b)

so we write (here t is the multiplicity of Œª in c, that we know it is at least 2):

  • a + b = Œª^(3*t-2) * x
  • a + Œ∑ * b = Œª * y
  • a + Œ∑ ^ 2 * b = Œª * z

we know that x, y and z are pairwise coprime, and that

x * y * z = u * w^3 (1)

where c = Œª ^ t * w
this is all done in Lean
Now, we move from (1) to the corresponding equality for ideals
so we have that the product of three pairwise coprime ideals is a cube in a PID, so each generator is a cube up to a unit, and this is the next math step
this is where we write x = u‚ÇÅ * X^3, and similarly for y and z

Kummer's lemma enters into the story because playing with X, Y, Z and u‚ÇÅ, u‚ÇÇ, u‚ÇÉ, we can prove that

Y ^ 3 +u‚ÇÑ * Z ^ 3 = u‚ÇÖ * (Œª ^ (t - 1) * X) ^ 3

where u‚ÇÑ and u‚ÇÖ are explicit.

Now, this looks like the original equation (the one we want to do the descent on), but there is an extraneous u‚ÇÑ. Looking modulo Œª^2 and using kummer's lemma, we get u‚ÇÑ = ¬±1 (since cubes not 0 modulo Œª^2 are ¬±1 mod Œª^2, and nothing is 0 mod Œª^2 in this equation), so we have

Y ^ 3 +(u‚ÇÑ * Z) ^ 3 = u‚ÇÖ * (Œª ^ (t - 1) * X) ^ 3
this essentially finishes the proof
